SAME SCENE, PERHAPS AN HOUR LATER
BRUCH VIOLIN CONCERTO NO. 1 IN G MINOR
EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE, HAMPSTEAD, LONDON. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we look down a gentle rain is falling steadily on a carapace of umbrellas, moving like the scales of some gigantic mythical reptile. The reptile turns out to be a dressed crowd swirling around the entrance to the hall an funnelling slowly into it; the same rain rolling down pos advertising the event they’ve all come to see: the debut concert of David Eli Rapoport, 21 year-old virtuoso violinist.

dialogues.speaker: BBC RADIO PRESENTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It is sometimes said that both the shortest and the longest distance in art is that between the very good and the truly great. It may well be that tonight David Eli Rapoport will cross that divide. Those of us who have been privileged to hear his promotional recording are unanimous in declaring the extraordinary playing of this 21-year-old Polish immigrant music from the gods, the voice of possibly the most naturally gifted violinist of his generation... Cars are passing, Festival of Britain flags flying from t building. Pasted across its facade are monochrome publici blow-ups of the lean and Byronic Rapoport and, plastered diagonally across the posters, strip banners reading: “INTERNATIONAL DEBUT PERFORMANCE 7:30 P.M. NOVEMBER 3RD, 1951, with another, smaller strip overplastered: “SOLD OU RETURNS ONLY”. Touts are busy in the crowd, selling outrageously priced tickets to those who have come without one; there’s a pol presence for crowd control - bobbies in glistening rain c - a phalanx of damp press photographers, a St John’s ambulance crew on stand-by. Limousines are delivering DIGNITARIES to the front steps, chauffeurs and assistants shepherding them inside under umbrellas. Big event.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FINDS 21 YEAR-OLD MARTIN SIMMONDS
dialogues.text: standing at the open stage door, anxiously scanning the w street and checking his watch. After a few moments he goe back inside.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.2 INT. LONDON CONCERT HALL, NIGHT (CONTINUOUS) (A’51) 2 Here there’s every shade of anxiety. The capacity audienc buzzing with restlessness; the orchestra waits in silence having long ago finished tuning up. The BBC RADIO PRESENTER whose voice we’ve been hearing ca seen in the recording booth, holding on to his audience during the delay in the relaxed filibuster style we assoc with Richard Dimbleby at the Coronation [still two years the future].

dialogues.speaker: BBC RADIO PRESENTER
dialogues.text: So great has been the impact of Rapoport’s recording on the world of classical music that one tends to forget how little known his name still is, and that tonight’s concert will be his first on an international stage... BACKSTAGE there’s a frenzy of activity and a sliding scal panic: from the irritation of those mildly inconvenienced the soloist’s lateness to the near hysteria of those most affected, chief among them

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT SIMMONDS
dialogues.text: Gilbert, the concert’s promoter, is a 56 year-old English gentleman-impresario. He’s standing with his wife, ENID ( and Martin’s fiancée, 21 year-old HELEN. Their son, Marti rejoins them as we watch, shaking his head. All are weari evening dress and all are agitated, though none as much a Gilbert.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: He’s had an accident. There’s no other explanation-

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: We don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Martin, I’d like you to phone the hospitals.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I already did, Father. Mr Sanderson's doing it again now. ANGLE ON SANDERSON, the theatre manager, talking urgently the backstage phone.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Has anyone informed the police?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Too soon for that.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018)

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: How was he this afternoon? Was he all right at rehearsal?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He was fine.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Did he take his violin with him?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He takes it everywhere. He takes it to the loo. p.3 Gilbert shoots his son a disapproving look. Offended by t indelicacy of the comment or by Martin’s attitude?

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: Gilbert, stop working yourself up into a froth. Perhaps his watch stopped.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: A self-winding wristwatch does not stop.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: It does if you drop it.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He might’ve got stuck in traffic.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Where did he say was he going after the rehearsal?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Dovidl does things his own way, Mr Simmonds. He’s probably walking. He likes walking in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: With a Gagliano under his arm? (crossing to stage entrance) Have you seen who’s out there?

dialogues.speaker: THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Several distinguished-looking men and women waiting.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.4

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Peers of the realm, members of Parliament, The Times music critic. Such people are not kept waiting-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He'll be here. This means as much to him as it does to you.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Does it really?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I know-

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: You don’t know. I’m not talking about money.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: He could be lying in a gutter somewhere - hurt, dead... ANGE ON AUDITORIUM CLOCK: showing 7:50 BACK TO GILBERT- by now on the edge of tears. The orchestra conductor is looking his way, tapping his watch, tilting his head enquiringly. Time to cancel.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: They’1l1 have to be told.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Want me to do it? Gilbert shakes his head. Steps through on to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: My Lords, ladies and gentlemen... (voice quivering) It is with great regret that I have to tell you... the performer you have come to see is unable to be here this evening... (gestures helplessly) Refunds may be claimed at the box office. He hurries offstage, holding back his tears.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE, HAMPSTEAD, LONDON. DAY
dialogues.text: TITLE: “35 YEARS LATER”  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.5 A black cab pulls up outside the house and sounds its hor Imposing and costly when it was built in the 1920’s and o by the Simmonds family ever since, the house is now run d and in need of repair and repainting. In the double drive sits a single ten-year-old car: an anomaly in this afflue two-car neighbourhood. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (S’86) 4 The style inside the house is cultured, if a little shabb floor-to-ceiling bookshelves in the drawing room, full of mostly hardback volumes; a baby grand loaded with classic sheet music; somewhat old-fashioned furniture; soft furnishings in muted colours. A suitcase stands in the hall, an overcoat and umbrella draped across it, a briefcase leaning against it.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: MARTIN SIMMONDS is now in his mid-fifties, his body slim well kept. HELEN, whose cheek he is kissing in valedictio is still, at the same age, handsome.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (a ritual, this) Take your pills, don’t wear the same shirt twice, sell music.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Kiss Emily for me. The minute the baby’s born, stick it in front of the piano. You can’t start too soon.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: ‘It’ is a girl, Martin. The scan’s showing a girl. Granddaughter, not grand piano. I'll call you if I’m not asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And if the estimate for the roof comes, let me know straight away.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I might have to walk home. Save the train fare. The taxi’s horn sounds again.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.6 EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (S’86) 5 Martin emerges, coated, carrying suitcase and briefcase, umbrella hooked over his arm. He climbs into the waiting taxi. EXT. GATESHEAD RAILWAY STATION - PLATFORM. DAY (S’86) 6 Exiting the station, Martin is taken aback to find at the barrier the city’s Lord Mayor, CHARLIE FROGGATT (60+), in full regalia, and his driver.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Charlie Froggatt, look at you in your gold chain. Didn’t know this was a civic reception, I’d have worn my ermine underwear. The driver takes Martin’s suitcase. As they walk towards station exit:

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: (Tyneside accent) Just come from opening a DIY superstore. You’d think they’d do it themselves, wouldn’t you? INT. DAIMLER (TRAVELLING). DAY (S’86) 7

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: So you're still peddling sheet music, I see.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s a living. Libraries and schools buy it.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: How long you staying?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Just ‘til Friday.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: What are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hanging myself, I expect.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: How about doing an old friend a favour first?  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.7

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This old friend got any pull with the Libraries Committee?

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: You do one for me, I’1l do one for you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s how the Great War started. (a beat) What’s the favour?

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: Jury service. (off Martin’s reaction) Competition jury. Tyneside Young Musician of the Year. It’s world famous.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Not the world I live in.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: Under-18's who’ve slipped through the music education net - they actually play an instrument. You'd be non-playing Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You've got to be joking.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: I never joke about Tyneside. You'd just be a figurehead. Like me. You're still a name in the music world, man. Your dad knew Paderewski, for Chrissake.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m not my father, Charlie. And he didn’t judge Paderewski’s musicianship.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: We've got a couple of long-hairs in for that - Tom Noble and Jenny Burrows, you know Jenny. You get the casting vote if they hang.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Forget it, Charlie. I’m here to sell, not buy.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: These kids are next year’s customers. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.8 FROGGATT (cont'd) Chairman of the Libraries Committee happens to be my grandson's girlfriend's uncle.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Talk about connected! EXT. GATESHEAD - DAY (S’86) The limo crossing the Tyne Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pick you up at eight. INT. COMMUNITY HALL,GATESHEAD. NIGHT (S’86) A packed hall, an old Steinway grand onstage. Below the stage, seated at a trestle table, the panel of five COMPETITION JUDGES: Martin at their centre, JENNY BURROWS (50) on his left, TOM NOBLE (68) on his right. CHARLIE FROGGATT onstage in his mayoral regalia.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: ..-and I have every confidence this year’s finalists will maintain the high musical standard for which Tyneside is justly famous.... Shouts of approval from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Vienna of the north-east.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: So without further ado, let competition commence, and may music speak louder than words. He sits down to modest applause.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGES COMPLETING THEIR MARK SHEETS
dialogues.text: The first finalist is a 10 YEAR-OLD GIRL playing the Bach Chaconne for clarinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home-made, on council-headed notepaper, the mark sheets a divided into three hand-drawn columns headed “TECHNIQUE”, “INTERPRETATION” and “MUSICALITY”, with a fourth column f totals. The girl’s scores out of ten are uniformly in the four-five range. She scores lowest on interpretation.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.9 - AN 11 YEAR-OLD BOY CELLIST playing Kreisler’s Liebeslei with piano accompaniment. He’s good for his age but in no outstanding. Fives and the odd six. - THE ADJUDICATORS, starting to look glazed. Jenny glanci at her watch. - 16 year-old MARIA KORVINSKY, rippling off Beethoven's Bagatelle in G Minor as though warming up. The audience applause is appropriately mighty. The judges are smiling now, lavishing nines and tens. Gol found in a midden. Barring a further miracle, they’ve got their winner.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (through applause) Can we go home now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: One genius, Jenny. Might be two.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Aye, well, it is Gateshead. FROGGATT has come back onstage.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: Our final Young Musician hails from South Shields. He’s 14 years old and has already toured internationally with the Tyneside Youth Orchestra...

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (aside) Wales and the Isle of Man.

dialogues.speaker: FROGGATT
dialogues.text: ...So please put your hands together for Peter Stemp. PETER STEMP, a bad acne case, steps onstage and readies himself to play his three-year-old Japanese fiddle. ANGLE ON ELLEN STEMP (40), his proud mother, in the front of the audience. Then Peter does something very odd. Prior to playing his competition piece the boy reaches into his pocket, pulls a block of rosin and ritualistically swipes his bow strin with it - first a broad upward sweep, then a matching downward sweep. Finally, before putting the rosin away an tucking the violin back under his chin-

dialogues.speaker: HE TOUCHES THE ROSIN TO HIS LIPS
dialogues.text: 10 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.10 There are some titters from the audience at the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He isn’t tittering. His reaction is out of all keeping wi what has occurred. It’s a reaction of such shock and emot so sudden and overwhelming, that it has drained the colou from his face.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (to Martin) You all right, man? Martin doesn’t answer. Too stunned to speak. Peter begins to play the second movement of Tartini’s “Devil's Trill” Sonata for solo violin - a difficult piec beyond his skill level, and it shows. But though his musicianship is far from exceptional it’s clear that some at some time, has taught him some old-fashioned Kreisleri slides and a particular treatment of the rosin that very teachers would countenance and no violinist in the histor solo performance would ever exhibit in public... save onl one. ANGLE ON PETER STEMP as he plays, sliding inexpertly... ANGLE ON MARTIN as he listens... INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (A’39) 10 ..-and the playing changes, as the Tartini fades and we h an exuberant Wieniawski violin piece, played by an immeasurably superior violinist. ANGLE ON DAVID ELI RAPOPORT (DOVIDL), aged 9, as he plays sliding with arrogant Kreislerian exuberance...

dialogues.speaker: THE OPEN DOORWAY
dialogues.text: where 9 YEAR-OLD MARTIN is watching and listening from th hallway. The emotions on his young face: jealousy and resentment. The small drawing room audience is composed of GILBERT(44 here); ENID (39); PROFESSOR CARL FLESCH (58) - Hungarian- soloist and London’s most celebrated pre-war violin teach and ZYGMUNT RAPOPORT (40), Dovidl’s prematurely balding Polish-Jewish father, a Warsaw costume jeweller: not a refugee but with the abandoned worn-down look of one. Dovidl - black hair shiny as jet, legs stick-thin in calf length shorts - is playing with the flashy show-off style a child genius who knows that only time and practice stan between him and his birthright: world-renown as a virtuos Flesch and Gilbert are listening pleasurably, nodding, knowing it too.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p-l1l Martin is two months older than Dovidl. His grey flannel shorts are the right length for London juvenile fashion o the day - the only edge it seems he has on this exotic interloper. Dovidl finishes the piece. He looks up, awaiting requests an encore; spots Martin in the doorway, meets his eye briefly, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Professor Flesch? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: FLESCH
dialogues.text: Too many flourishes. (to Dovidl) You are not Kreisler, young man.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Kreisler is not Rapoport. A statement of calculated precocity. It brings chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: ZYGMUNT
dialogues.text: (to Flesch) You will teach him? He is genius.

dialogues.speaker: FLESCH
dialogues.text: I am sent ten geniuses a month, Pan Rapoport. If your son accepts that he has still something to learn, perhaps I can teach him something. You are staying in London?

dialogues.speaker: ZYGMUNT
dialogues.text: No, I go back to Warsaw, to my wife and daughters.... If I can find somebody to take David... I leave him here.

dialogues.speaker: FLESCH
dialogues.text: Safer. Given the situation in Poland.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (thoughtful) Very much so.

dialogues.speaker: ZYGMUNT
dialogues.text: Do you know of Jewish family, Mr Simmonds? I can pay a little...

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: As it happens I do have a family in mind, Mr Rapoport. It isn’t Jewish, but it is musical, and will cost you nothing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.12 GILBERT (cont'd) I can promise you the tenets of your religion would be fully respected, its requirements met in every regard. Gilbert looks across at his wife. He almost certainly has consulted her about this considerable commitment, an autocratic decision typical of the man. ENID gives nothin back - neither consent nor refusal, approval nor disappro Zygmunt is aware how great a commitment this is. It entai among other things, kosher food, Hebrew lessons, Sabbath observance. If he appears to hesitate, consider where he come from. Zygmunt cannot conceive of a Gentile Polish paterfamilias making such an offer.

dialogues.speaker: ZYGMUNT
dialogues.text: This is English family?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: It is. (a beat) My own son is David’s age. They would share a bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Outrage on his face. The brilliant interloper is to be admitted to residence, it seems, without any family consultation at all. Zygmunt's eyes are sparkling with tears. He embraces Gilb who stands stiffly to receive the embrace, embarrassed by this un-English gesture, not knowing where to put his han Stepping back, Zygmunt reaches into his pocket and pulls it a velvet-covered ring box. Ceremoniously he presents i his son, the tears overflowing now. The boy opens the box

dialogues.speaker: RING BOX
dialogues.text: The inside lid is stamped, in gold leaf lettering: “RAPOP WARSZAWA”. But there is no ring inside. Only a small ambe block of rosin, pristine and gleaming. Everybody smiles as Dovidl removes the rosin and swipes i experimentally along his bow strings: first with a stylis upward flourish, then with a downward. He touches the ros to his lips. Gilbert and Zygmunt applaud. It’s a subtle little ritual whose meaning seems to have eluded ENID, the giving of th box: partly a jeweller’s joke, partly an expression of ho partly a father’s farewell blessing.  11 12 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.13 With his ritualistic stroking of the bow Dovidl has improvised a witty variation: taking the rosin for a run, it were, as though the gift had been a Stradivarius. The on the rosin is for his father, whom he is aware he may n see again. [For Peter Stemp 47 years later it will be a magical ritual entirely without meaning. ] EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (A’39) 11 His cardboard suitcase at his feet, Zygmunt is about to l for the bus stop, first leg of his journey back to Poland to what we now know will be invasion, occupation, ghetto death camp - and though he doesn’t know what he’s returni to, Zygmunt seems to intuit it. Hence the passion he puts into his last tearful embrace of the son he may never see again. To Martin and his parents, watching from the doorstep, th is yet another public display of emotion that makes them uncomfortable. It isn’t anti-Semitism, it isn’t coldness; it’s English reserve. INT. HOTEL DINING ROOM, GATESHEAD. DAY (S’86) 12 The day following the competition Martin is lunching with Peter Stemp and his mother, ELLEN (46): a woman of modest means, wearing her best two-piece for the occasion. On the table is The Northern Echo: international and loca news with a Tyneside flavour; several column inches given last night’s music competition: picturing a toothy Maria Korvinsky accepting her prize from Mayor Froggatt.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: So what’s this about? You didn’t give Peter the prize, now we’re having this posh lunch. Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That wasn’t my decision.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You'd have made him the winner, then? If it was up to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: The girl’s already there, Mrs Stemp. Peter needs more time... better tuition. (attempting the casual) Who's been teaching him?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: He gets lessons in school. I can’t afford fancy teachers.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.14

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We could discuss that.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Know a good cheap one, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Several good, none cheap.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: In South Shields?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: London.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Just have to sell the yacht, then, won't I?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'll find a way to cover Peter's tuition during his school holidays. And a family in London he can stay with. Ellen looks to Peter. He’s nodding. Wants it.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: (indicates newspaper) Why him? Why not what’s-her-face?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Her too.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: You think Pete’s that good, then?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He’1ll never be a Heifetz. But he could make a living with an orchestra. Or teaching. (to Peter) Who's been teaching you, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: School.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And who else? You've had a few tips off someone. Peter shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That thing you do with the rosin....  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That’s for good luck. I can stop.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What’s his name? Maybe I know him. A moment of hesitation, then-

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don’t know him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I think I might. He used to be a virtuoso. Did he tell you that? Peter smiling now.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: DSark hair, about my age?

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: It’s not Pete you want, is it? A harshness has entered her voice. She’s worked bursary, the promise of a management contract - something other than Peter Stemp.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Come on, Pete. We’re going. (to Martin) Thanks for the dinner. p.15 it out. The they’re about Taking Peter by the hand, she pulls him to his feet. They leave the dining room without looking back. 13 INT. MARTIN’S HOTEL ROOM, GATESHEAD. NIGHT (S’86) 13 Martin is perched on his bed, on the phone to Helen.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (to phone) What are they calling it? Sorry, her. (winces ) Lovely name. Kiss little Cressida for me, I'll see her Sunday. (a pause) Helen...? I think I might have found him. There’s no response. No request to identify the silence. “him”. Just  14 15 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.16

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said? INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (SIMULTANEOUS) (S’86) 14 Helen’s in bed, her book set aside to take Martin’s call.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (to phone, tonelessly) I heard. Goodnight, Martin. INT. MARTIN’S BEDROOM, SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (A’39) 15 This is the first time Martin and Dovidl have been left a together. Dovidl is in the bedroom doorway with his cheap suitcase between his feet, waiting to be invited in.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (heavily accented) I sleep here, yes?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. I don’t want you in my room. I like being on my own.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Is not your choose.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Wrong, clever. It is my “choose”. I have to say if it’s all right and if it isn’t you go back to Poland, and the Germans are going to invade Poland. You’1l have to wear a yellow star and get bashed up by brownshirts.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: What is “bashed up”, please? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You better not snore, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: What is snore? Martin does the sound for him. Dovidl pulls a small noteb and pencil from his pocket and records the word.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: If I snore I snore in tune. I am musician. You play?  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.17

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Piano, a bit.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Is good for accompanist. Chess?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: A bit.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (grins) Everything for you is bit. I am genius. I help you, you will be bit genius.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Bet I could get you down. Dovidl’s pencil gets busy a second time. Another new word

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: What is “get down”, please? Martin jumps him. Operative definition. The boys wrestle, grunting and snorting. But eventually i the wiry Dovidl who wrestles Martin to the ground and sit on his chest, pinning his arms.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Also fight a bit.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (terminal frustration) Bloody foreigner! You can’t even talk proper English!

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: You speak Polish? Russian? Yiddish? German? Hebrew?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t have to. I’m not one of your lot.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: What is “lot”?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Foreigners. We’re in England, stupid. Dovidl climbs off him, retrieves his notebook; wags it.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Wait six months.  16 17 18 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.18

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What’s your name, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Dovid Eli Rapoport. My family call me Dovidl. You?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Martin L. Simmonds.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I call you Mottl. INT. GATESHEAD HOTEL BEDROOM. MORNING (S’86) 16 Martin is eating a room-service breakfast at a small whee table when there’s a tentative knock at the door. He open to:

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Peter. Where’s your mother? He checks the corridor. No Ellen. Came alone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I‘1l take you to him. EXT. GATESHEAD. DAY (S’86) 17 They've come by taxi to an underpass entrance: a pedestri tunnel beneath a busy urban road. EXT/INT. SUBWAY. DAY (S’86) 18 As Martin and Peter descend the steps we’1ll hear a dista violin playing - with only moderate competence - The Roll Stones’ “Paint it Black”. Martin’s face falls. Whoever is playing, it isn’t Dovidl. As they get closer, so does the music. A turn in the tunn reveals...

dialogues.speaker: A BUSKER
dialogues.text: The busker is BILLY, an unkempt grizzly-bearded man in hi seventies, wearing a stained raincoat, football socks and dirty plimsolls. He’s playing on a cheap fiddle - complet with unwanted echoes off the tiled walls. On the floor at feet, among the crisp packets and banana skins, is his ca dotted with a handful of low-value coins.  19 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.19 Though he’d known from the first bow-stroke that this cou not be Dovidl, Martin wilts with disappointment. Billy nods an acknowledgement at Peter but barely glances Martin as he finishes the piece with a flourish of poorly executed Kreisleresque slides. Then out comes the rosin, followed by that ritualistic up-and-down stroking of the bowstrings with which we’re becoming familiar, and the valedictory kiss to the rosin, a magical ritual as meaningless to Billy as it is to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This is Mr Simmonds, Billy. He's gonna pay for me to have lessons. In London.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (London accent) What did I tell you? (to Martin) Told him he’d get discovered.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He says you’ve been helping him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (laughs) Showed him a couple of things.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Where did you learn to play?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Taught meself. Martin takes out his wallet. Extracts a fiver, drops it i the hat.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Teach yourself those Kreisler slides, did you, Billy? Billy's face sets.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Who wants to know?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Your best customer. INT. CAFE, GATESHEAD. DAY (S’86) 19 Billy, Peter and Martin are drinking thick tea from thick white mugs at a formica-topped table.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.20

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He never told me his name. It was years ago.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Where did you meet him?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: London. I used to work the cinema queues up west - when they had cinema queues. I wasn’t bad then-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What year?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (thinks ) High Noon. When was that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: 452, I think. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So I’m outside the Odeon, yeah, playing the theme music - you know, from the film - and this cheeky little bugger comes up, tells me I could do with some lessons. ‘Oh, yeah,’ I says. ‘Who from?’ ‘I don’t normally give lessons,’ he says, only he’s saving up for this trip he wants to go on, so how much can I afford to pay him? I told him to get knotted. Don’t even know he can play, do I?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I assume he demonstrated.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Takes me violin right out me hand. You never heard nothing like it in your life. Magic. Like something off the wireless. (shakes his head in wonder) Crowd starts chucking half crowns, ten-bob notes. I give him half. Fair's fair, right?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What did he look like?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Like he could do with a square meal.  20 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.21

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: When was the last time you saw him?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Important, is it? Martin deposits another fiver on the sticky table top.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He give me a few lessons. Twice a week for a bit. One day he didn’t turn up. Never saw him again. Must’ve gone on his trip.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Did he say where?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Didn’t make much sense, like, but that’s why I remember it. Martin waits. Billy waits. Another fiver goes down.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Said he was going home to play for the Ashes. That’s cricket, innit? When England plays Australia. (Martin nods) Didn’t make sense ‘cos he didn’t sound like an Aussie. ‘Who’re you, then?’ I says. ‘Don bleeding Bradman?’

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: His exact words? Billy’s brow furrows with the effort of recall.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Something about a song. Going home - to play a song. (a beat) For the ashes.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARTIN
dialogues.text: This doesn’t mean anything to us but it contains a world meaning for Martin. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (A’39) 20 A family dinner is being eaten in silence as everybody listens to the evening news on the wireless. It’s a Frida night and for Dovidl’s benefit there are Sabbath candles the table and a loaf of chala wrapped in a white cloth.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.22 We should note that Dovidl’s dinner plate contains differ food from the others’, mostly vegetables. The news is all about the German Blitzkrieg of Poland: th bombing of Warsaw, the collapse of the Polish army. The Phoney War is a few days old. Dovidl’'s face reflects his struggle to contain his emoti He’s learning to be English.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: I’m sure your family will be all right, David.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: Have you written home, David?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I am writing letter.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Good lad.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: You permit I make more letter now?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Permission granted, old chap. As Dovidl prepares to leave the table-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He hasn’t finished his dinner.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Special dispensation. Go and finish your letter, David. Dovidl slides off his seat and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s not fair.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: What isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: All this. No bacon allowed in the house, no milk puddings, special food for the genius, and he doesn’t even have to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: If you'd like to take over preparing David’s food you may have a say in whether he eats it.  21 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.23

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And he’s a liar. He stopped writing two weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: It isn’t very nice, Martin, to tell tales on a friend.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: My friends don’t wet the bed. The Simmonds adults exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Considering the position his family is in, I'd say wetting the bed is the least we can expect from him.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Why don’t you go and see if you can cheer him up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Didn’t look all that down to me.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: That’s a wicked thing to say! Go to your room!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Not my room, is it. He goes. INT. LANDING/THE BOYS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT (A’39) 21 Through the partly open door we catch Dovidl looking at a photograph and crying. It’s a sepia studio portrait of th Rapoport family taken in Warsaw in 1937: Dovidl’s father mother standing side by side; in front of them, Dovidl ag seven between his two sisters: Pessia (9) and Malkeh (5). Pessia has her arm around Dovidl’s shoulders; Dovidl’s ar around Malkeh’s. All five are solemn and unsmiling, in th portrait style of the time. As Martin enters Dovidl slides the photo under his pillow Martin doesn’t see it. Trying to recover his equilibrium, Dovidl blows his nose.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I have cold. A sudden unexpected shaft of compassion pierces Martin's juvenile soul.  22 23 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.24

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: They'll be all right. We’1ll smash the Jerries up for you. No-one stands up to the British Army.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: You are child.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Play you a game of chess if you want.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Chess with you takes my mind two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (a grin) Three. I feel lucky. EXT. HAMPSTEAD. DAY (A‘39) 22 The two boys are freewheeling down a hill on their bikes, playing “chicken”. Martin is the first to swerve - avoiding a horse-drawn mi float. Dovidl sails on, misses the float by inches, and i passing swipes a pint. Riding no-hands, he pierces the to with his finger while still on the move and swigs from th bottle. It’s Martin who gets nabbed by the milkman - momentarily caught by his coat - before he breaks away and pedals mad down the hill after Dovidl, who has disappeared from view

dialogues.speaker: MILKMAN
dialogues.text: Thieving little bleeders! EXT. HAMPSTEAD HEATH. DAY (A’39) 23 Martin finds Dovidl waiting in their private spot on the Heath: beneath a large tree, overlooking the Ponds. Eatin Kit Kat [N.B. Wartime issue: blue wrapper, dark chocolate price 3d]. Grinning in triumph, Dovidl offers Martin a finger of Kit Kat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Thought you said these weren’t kosher.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: You rabbi now?  24 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.25

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Where'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Your pocket. He proffers the milk bottle. Martin takes a swig.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: We make good team, yes? Embarrassed by Dovidl’s open acknowledgement of what in a London boy's world should remain implicit, Martin sprays with milk. Dovidl responds by jumping on him playfully. T wrestle standing up for a few moments, then both boys ste back to face one another and go by tacit agreement into t slow motion boxers routine. This consists of each delivering in turn a slo-mo punch w the other has the option either to dodge in slow motion o receive as a simulated blow, rocking back under the prete impact with appropriate facial grimaces. INT. HALLWAY, PROFESSOR FLESCH’S STUDIO. DAY (WINTER 1940 Dovidl has come for his violin lesson, accompanied by GILBERT. On the landing outside Flesch’s studio they meet JOZEF WECHSLER (18) about to descend. He’s carrying a ver old violin case, housing the virtuoso’s badge of office: very old violin.

dialogues.speaker: JOZEF
dialogues.text: Professor Flesch isn’t here. I’ve been waiting an hour.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Do you know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: JOZEF
dialogues.text: Back in Hungary, probably. He thinks the Waffen SS are coming over London Bridge. His glance, finding Dovidl, takes in his leatherette-cove violin case, doubtless containing a cheap violin.

dialogues.speaker: JOZEF
dialogues.text: (to Gilbert, with an inclination of the head) Jozef Wechsler. Of Warsaw. You will have heard of me.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Gilbert Simmonds. I believe Professor Flesch has mentioned you.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.26 Dovidl’s look is one of undisguised envy. Wechsler, alrea an international name at eighteen and with the arrogance young god, is who he wants to be - preferably tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (to Jozef) Dovid Eli Rapoport. Also of Warsaw. Professor Flesch has spoken of you to me also.

dialogues.speaker: JOZEF
dialogues.text: He hasn’t spoken of you. (to Gilbert) Your boy will need to find a new teacher. You know Dr Steiner of Leipzig?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: I know of him.

dialogues.speaker: JOZEF
dialogues.text: He has played Mozart with Einstein. He is in London now.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I learn physics, I go Einstein.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Mr Wechsler isn’t recommending Einstein as a violin teacher, David.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I practise alone.

dialogues.speaker: JOZEF
dialogues.text: And from whom will you learn humility?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Not from you. With a sad shake of the head, Jozef leaves. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (W’40) 25 Having returned home, Gilbert and Dovidl enter the living room to find Martin practising at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (to Dovidl) Actually, Steiner’s not a bad idea.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.27

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I do not need teacher. Only to practise.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Who will make sure you don’t skip the tricky bits when your fingers are hurting? Martin swings around on the piano stool.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How about me?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Hah. Boy of ten.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Older than you.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Fifty-five days older... (calculating) .»»-one point five-one percent. One- and-six out of a fiver. Small change.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s six Kit Kats-

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Boys! Please. It’s a very mature undertaking.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m more mature than he is.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Hah. This initiates another ritual. Momentarily forgetting his father’s presence, Martin jumps off the stool and launche into the slow motion boxers routine.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Boys, if you’ve finished demonstrating your maturity - They stop.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Suppose some difficulty were to arise that I needed to know about, and your friend asked you to keep it from me. Wouldn’t that be a conflict of loyalties?  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.28

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: My loyalty’s to you, Father. Gilbert puts his arms around both boys’ shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: We'll give it a go. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. DAY (S’86) 26 Returning from Gateshead, Martin lugs his suitcase into t house. He finds Helen in the living room, marking school essays and too absorbed to hear him enter. He crosses to kisses the nape of her neck.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I might've been a burglar.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: With his own key?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Locksmith by trade. How's Emily?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Blooming.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And little Isolde? What was it?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Cressida. Can’t read, write or play a note but she knows her name. You’1l see her tomorrow. A pause. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: How was your trip?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I made back the train fare. A longer pause.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: So? What did you find?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Dovidl was still in London in 1952.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: There’s a hot trail for you.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.29

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It means whatever his reason for not turning up, it wasn’t because he was dead. We never knew that for sure before.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Just because he was alive thirty- odd years ago doesn’t mean he is now.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He’s our age. Why wouldn’t he be?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: This going to be your new hobby, Martin? Finding David after half a lifetime so he can spit in your eye again?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If you'd lost a brother-

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (cutting in) He wasn’t your brother.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He felt like a brother.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: And what do I feel like?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: To you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This isn’t a competition.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Everything's a competition. Read your Darwin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Helen, I’m tired, I’m hungry, I need a bath and I don’t want to have this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Then we’ll have it later, when you're fed and rested.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, you can do it solo - both parts. I’1l be the audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.30 He turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Where did he go in 1952?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I thought you weren’t interested.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Historical curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Poland. He went to Poland. He goes out and closes the door behind him. Helen remains her chair but does not resume her marking. EXT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. EARLY EVENING (A’40) 26A Blast tape on the windows of houses. A car passes with it headlights shaded. A military lorry drops Gilbert at the house. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. EARLY EVENING (CONTINUOUS) (A’40) 27 Same room as Scenes 25 and 26, same piano, but with the furnishings of the period; complete with taped windows an not-yet-drawn blackout curtains. No lights are on and the room is gloomy. Barely able to see his music, Martin is at the piano, accompanying Dovidl; playing chords to which Dovidl is practising his staccato technique. Suddenly Dovidl stops playing. Martin carries on for a mo or two before he registers this. Then he, too, stops; swi on the stool to face Dovidl.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I didn’t say you could stop.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: My neck is hurting. [N.B. Dovidl’s English is already far less heavily accent

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s supposed to. He swivels back to the keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I have done enough.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.31 Martin swivels back to Dovidl.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I decide when you’ve done enough. Dovidl picks up his violin case.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’1l tell him, Dov. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Tittle-tattle.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Baby. Gilbert enters the room, wearing an ARP armband (Air Raid Precaution - a warden).

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Sorry to interrupt, boys. He crosses to the window, closes the blackout curtains, switches on the light.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now you can see what you're doing. Silence from the boys.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How are your Hebrew lessons going David? Happy with Mr Rosenthal’s teaching? I know you were getting along well with Mr. Cohen.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (proudly) He joined up. R.A.F.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. Important that you keep on with your religious studies. I promised your father. As Gilbert turns away;

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: They do not say Hebrew words same as in Poland, Mr. Simmonds

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Then... He’s about to recommend that Dovidl learn the British sty of pronunciation, but in that instant realises that the European style may soon cease to exist.  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.31A

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Say them the way you were taught in Poland.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Simmonds.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (to Martin) How’s the violin coming along? Martin exchanges a look with Dovidl. If he’s going to rat out, this is the moment. It’s a long moment.  28 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.32

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: What’s he working on?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Staccato, Mr Simmonds.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Good, good. (indicating window) Well, you may as well keep at it till Herr Hitler's Gétterdammerung starts up. He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You owe me one.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: How you make that out?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I could've told him. I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: View from the piano stool. Here is standing view: I know you should tell him. I know you did not. He does not know it. But as Martin begins to play THE AIR RAID SIREN starts up moment later the electricity fails and the lights go off. EXT. AIR RAID SHELTER ENTRANCE. SAME NIGHT (A’40) 28 The promised Gétterdammerung. Bombs falling, the flash of incendiaries, searchlights and tracer illuminating the sk Gilbert, Enid, Martin and Dovidl are descending the steps into the shelter: Enid and Martin lugging blankets, therm flasks, sandwiches; Dovidl carrying only his violin case. Dovidl stops to look up at the light show in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You want to get killed?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Is not my destiny. It would have been like this - Warsaw would have been like this.  29 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.33

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Couldn’t have been worse. Come on. Dovidl doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, if we’re okay they probably are too. Your mum and dad, your sisters. They’d have had the sense to go to the shelters.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Look how beautiful it is.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s not art, Dovidl. It’s bloody life and death.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: So is art. A lone figure approaches, also heading for shelter: JOZEF WECHSLER (now nearly 20), carrying only his cased violin. Martin nudges Dovidl. Look who it is.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (to Martin) So what? You want plaque? “Jozef Wechsler cowered here, 1940."? Jozef passes without acknowledging them.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (to Jozef: attempting inclusiveness) Hampstead Shelter Orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: JOZEF
dialogues.text: What instrument do you play? Having delivered this majestic put-down, Wechsler surges regally past a Dovidl too stunned to reply. INT. AIR RAID SHELTER. NIGHT (A’40) 29 Jozef has settled among the crowd, camped as far as possi from the Simmondses. As Martin, Gilbert and Enid busy themselves spreading blankets and pillows, Dovidl removes his modest little vi from its case. He strokes the bowstrings with his block o Warsaw rosin, kisses the rosin, then casually begins to p a jaunty classical piece.  30 31 Yellow - SoN D9.3 (11/15/2018) p.34-34A Gilbert’s face displays pride; Jozef is trying to show am indifference. But it seems there’s only so much a genius stand. Unable to resist, Jozef at last takes up his own venerable instrument and joins in, merging seamlessly wit Dovidl. There is no apparent disparity in skill between t two performers and what at first seems a co-operative exercise soon grows savagely competitive- -as Jozef switches suddenly to a more demanding piece- -and Dovidl matches him effortlessly, bar for bar, finess for finesse- -and Dovidl switches to a notoriously tricky Paganini cap -and Jozef meets the challenge unerringly. Both of them smiling. Jozef thinking: ‘This kid’s not half bad.’ EXT WARSAW AIRPORT. DAY (S’86) 30 A British Airways plane is about to land... ...-Martin exits the terminal and climbs into a taxi EXT. WARSAW. DAY (S’86) 31 Martin’s taxi on its way from the airport to the city cen

dialogues.speaker: TAXI
dialogues.text: This is a Warsaw far removed from the pre-war city Dovidl would have known as a boy but not much different from the he visited in 1953, except that Solidarnosc flags and hoardings proliferate along the roadside and on the facad of buildings. The TAXI DRIVER is a man in his seventies. The car radio playing softly in the background.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Does Warsaw have a Musicians’ Union?

dialogues.speaker: WARSAW TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: No English.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Un-i-on. Music?

dialogues.speaker: WARSAW TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: Nie rozumiem. The driver turns up the volume on his radio.  Yellow - SoN D9.3 (11/15/2018) p.34-340A

dialogues.speaker: ON MARTIN
dialogues.text: The search isn’t going to be as easy as he thought.  32 Yellow - SoN D9.3 (11/15/2018) p.35 EXT. HAMPSTEAD STREET. DAY (S’43) 32 More than two years after the Blitz, London has taken an unexpected overnight pasting from the Luftwaffe. The boys standing on the rim of a smoking bombsite, holding their bikes, peering into the rubble.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Thought we had the Blitz two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: This is a footnote. (a beat) Look, there’s a body. ANGLE - an arm protruding from behind a half-demolished w  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.36 Martin follows Dovidl as he picks his way over the rubble towards it. He stoops to retrieve something shiny. He hol it up for Martin to see. A silver bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Has it got a name on it? Dovidl shakes his head. Pockets the bracelet. He moves out of sight behind the wall, which has a carpet staircase still intact against it. Martin pulls a Kit Kat bar from his pocket; unwraps it an takes a bite, surveying the wreckage as he munches. A mom or two passes, then Dovidl reappears, a purse in his hand

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (horrified) What are you doing!?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: It’s Mrs Harris. She’s on my paper round. The face is gone but I recognise the purse. He opens the purse, and with a triumphant yell extracts a pound note.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Treasure of the Mummy’s Tomb!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (appalled) Do you know what you get for robbing the dead?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Pound notes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: A firing squad. Dovidl makes his way over to where Martin is standing and passes him without pausing, flapping the banknote.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Eighty Kit Kats, Mott.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (calling after him) It isn’t yours!

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I don’t mind sharing. Reaching the street, he mounts his bike and pedals away.  33 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.37 EXT. HAMPSTEAD HEATH. DAY (LATER) (S’43) 33 They've repaired to their private spot on the Heath to sm cigarettes and drink brown ale from bottles. Dovidl is setting out on the grass an array of raunchy playing card each depicting a nude woman in a saucy pose.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Who do you fancy? The ace of clubs has the best tits, the four of diamonds is the best bum.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Your bar mitzvah's in ten days, Dov. You’re supposed to be a man. Looking at pictures of naked women doesn’t make you a man.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Neither does watching Shirley Smith undress through binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That was a scientific experiment.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: In what? Team wanking? Anyway, you don’t look like a man.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Neither do you.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: More than you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Bollocks.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: That too.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Being a man doesn’t mean that, does it?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: What are you now, a Talmud scholar? What does it mean, O wise one?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Among other things, respecting the dead.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Why? Because they’re dead? Out of interest, are they supposed to know they’re being respected?  34 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.38

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Their loved ones know.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Mrs Harris didn’t have any loved ones. No-one’s going to miss her. Mind you, she made good fishcakes. I’ll miss her fishcakes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (truly appalled) Is that all she meant to you?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This was a human person, Dov. She probably went to bed last night planning to... I don’t know, make fishcakes, and she ends up dead in the rubble of her house. Don’t you feel anything? Dovidl turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Do you know how many people died last night, Mottl? I don’t just mean in London. Across Occupied Europe. Shot, bayonetted, blown up, starved, burnt alive, hung-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s not the point.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Tens of thousands. And no-one even knows their names. So tell me, little man from NW3, which ones do I have to “feel” for? All of them or just the ones I trip over the morning after? INT. SYNAGOGUE. DAY (S’43) 34

dialogues.speaker: DISCOVER GILBERT AND MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sitting together at the back, wearing skullcaps for respe but as out of place as Hottentots at a Greek wedding. The attracting curious looks from the regular congregation (t being the synagogue Dovidl regularly attends), none of wh have seen them here before. CAMERA FINDS ENID, alone in the women’s section, even mor isolated.  35 36 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.39

dialogues.speaker: ON DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Wearing a dark blue suit and embroidered silk kippah, the mitzvah boy is at the bimah, fluently reciting his Hebrew Torah portion.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (...)Lay yisyatzev ish bifneychem: pakhd’khem umayraakhem yiten Adonay Elaykhekhem al penay khol hooretz asher tidrekhi vah, kaasher diber lokhem. The Torah is covered.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Borikh atoh Adonay, Elayheyni melekh hoaylom, asher nosan loni tayras emes v’khayei aylom nota b’saykheni. Borikh ato Adonai nayseyn hatayroh.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (---) No man shall stand up to you: the LORD your God will put the dread and the fear of you over the whole land in which you set foot, as He promised you.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: We praise You, Eternal God, Sovereign of the Universe: You have given us a Torah of truth, implanting within us eternal life. We praise You, O God, Giver of the Torah.

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: Shekoyach! May your force grow! EXT. FRYDERYK CHOPIN UNIVERSITY OF MUSIC. DAY (S’86) 35 A ‘modern’ concrete structure in central Warsaw, built in sixties. INT. FRYDERYK CHOPIN UNIVERSITY OF MUSIC. DAY (S’86) 36 Photographs of prominent Polish musicians decorate the wa several violinists among them. Away down the corridor a chamber orchestra can be heard practising. Martin arrives at the door to an administrative office. Inside he finds a middle-aged female RECEPTIONIST.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Dobry dzien, Pani. No response. Obviously doesn’t speak her own language.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you speak English? The receptionist tilts her head. A tentative yes, possibl

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a violinist - David Eli Rapoport. He isn’t one of your graduates but he might have performed here in the ‘fifties... INT. ARCHIVE, F. CHOPIN UNIVERSITY OF MUSIC. DAY (S’86) 3 A secretary produces a heavy bound volume and plops it do in front of Martin. INSERT LIST OF NAMES as Martin scans it. Hundreds of names and dates of graduation. Many names end in -SKI and -ISCZ. Radivicz... Rakowicz... Razinsky. No Rapoports.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: These are all graduates of the school. Isn’t there a record of musicians who've played here?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: For record store you go Srédmiescie.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t mean a recording. A written record. He taps the book sharply in demonstration. The secretary responds by closing the book with a snap. His tap seen as violation.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARTIN
dialogues.text: Although he didn’t expect instant success, his expression shows his disappointment. He realizes it’s a hopeless tas without at least a working knowledge of Polish.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Dziekuje Ci. He turns and leaves. INT./EXT. BAILEY’S OF BROADWICK STREET. NIGHT (S’43) 37 Gilbert arrives by taxi with the two boys outside one of London’s most venerable musical instrument sellers. INT. BAILEY’S. NIGHT (S’43) 38 He is greeted warmly by ADRIAN BAILEY (57) as a valued customer of long standing. Dismissing Martin with a glanc Bailey contemplates Dovidl appraisingly.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.41

dialogues.speaker: BAILEY
dialogues.text: How old is the boy ?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: The boy’s thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: A man, Mr Bailey - in David's culture. Taking Dovidl’s left hand in both his own, Bailey flexes Dovidl’s fingers.

dialogues.speaker: BAILEY
dialogues.text: Good fingers. (to Gilbert) Do you have a luthier in mind?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Nothing outrageously expensive, Mr Bailey. But a good one.

dialogues.speaker: BAILEY
dialogues.text: Let’s leave the Strads to the millionaires. I have something special for him. Bailey smiles, then disappears into a back room. Martin is scowling. A few moments of awkward silence pass before Bailey retur holding a worn violin case and a bow. He sets the case do and extracts the instrument. At the sight of it Dovidl’s eyes gleam with avarice.

dialogues.speaker: BAILEY
dialogues.text: This is a Nicolo Gagliano filio. He hands bow and violin to Dovidl, who receives them with reverence due a holy relic.

dialogues.speaker: BAILEY, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: The son of Alessandro Gagliano made this instrument in 1735, the year of his father’s death. Many think it was a tribute violin. (to Dovidl) And your father-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Foster father.  39 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.42 Gilbert glares at his son.

dialogues.speaker: BAILEY
dialogues.text: -..-does not have to be Rothschild to afford it.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Happy bar mitzvah, David.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Where’s mine? Forced laughter from the two men. If Gilbert is aware how cruel he’s being to his natural son he isn’t showing it. But Dovidl is too distracted to spare a thought for Marti He’s examining the instrument with a lustful eye. Taking the ring box from his pocket, he extracts his bloc rosin, swipes the bowstrings with it - once up, once down then kisses the rosin. Bailey shoots Gilbert an enquiring look but no explanation is offered. Dovidl has tucked the Gagliano under his chin and is test its range and resonance, playing short snatches of music various styles and in rapid succession. A smile of pleasure extends across Bailey’s face.

dialogues.speaker: BAILEY
dialogues.text: (to Gilbert) See how she responds. It will be a happy marriage. INT. WARSAW HOTEL ROOM. NIGHT (S’86) 39 Martin is working the Warsaw phone book, calling any poss source he can think of. It’s another hopeless task, limit by his rudimentary Polish, the poor English of his interlocutors and scratchy phone connections.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (to phone) Rapoport. R-A-P-O-P-O-R-T. He would have been here from about the early 1950’s. I don’t know how long- (interrupted) Of course. Thank you anyway, Pani.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE, PERHAPS AN HOUR LATER
dialogues.text: Another phone call.  40 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.43

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (to phone, frustrated) No, I’m asking for your enquiry rates... (listens) Money. Pieniadze. Do you charge by the assignment or by the hour? (listens in frustration) I’m sorry to have troubled you. I’m afraid I need someone who speaks fluent English. Fluent Polish comes down the line.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (to himself) Q.E.D. Putting down the phone, he crosses to the window and stan looking out at the city. A train passing in the near distance triggers a memory... INT. LONDON RAILWAY TERMINUS. DAY (W’47) 40 GILBERT descends from the boat train with an ENSEMBLE OF MUSICIANS, their luggage and instrument cases plastered w Polish and other European travel stickers. Returning from two-week cultural tour of post-war Russian-occupied Polan Waiting at the platform entrance are MARTIN and DOVIDL, b now seventeen. Martin is still a pink-faced adolescent; Dovidl, already man-shaped, has a pronounced beard shadow the stricken, grief-rimmed eyes of an unconfirmed orphan. Those eyes searching Gilbert for news.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, David. I tried very hard, you must believe me.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Are you sure you went to the right address? Dzielna 21?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Your apartment - the tenement your family lived in... no longer exists, I’m afraid. Dovidl’s face. Gilbert places a sympathetic hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not the worst news, David. Definitely not the worst. (to Martin) Can you manage the cases?  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.44 ANGLE ON WARSAW STICKER ON SUITCASE as Martin lifts it. 41 INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (W’47) Al Same day. At dinner: Gilbert, Enid, Martin, Dovidl.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: (to Enid) David's family definitely survived the Ghetto. We know that much. They were deported before the Uprising in ‘43.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: Deported where? A pause. He hates even the word.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: Treblinka. Dovidl has already been told this but the terrible name shocks him anew.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: They're dead, Mrs Simmonds.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: No, David! That is not something we May assume. There was a mass revolt. Hundreds escaped. Hundreds. I will not give up the search and you must not give up hope. There are any number of places they could be - one of the DP camps, Russia, possibly-

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Why did you take Jozef Wechsler to Poland and not me? I play as well as he does.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: You’re not ready yet.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: I could've looked for myself. I speak Polish.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: So does Jozef, and what it got him was the worst news - confirmed by the Polish authorities. The other reason I didn’t take you is that I’m responsible for you in a way I am not for Jozef. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.45 GILBERT (cont'd) You're both Polish citizens - something we must rectify, by the way. They could have kept you there. Witness what happened to poor Jozef.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: His entire family’s gone. The Poles have kept him. (a beat) In an asylum. 42 INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (SAME EVENING) (W’47) 42 A search is underway for Dovidl. Gilbert comes in from th garden, his face fretted with concern.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: He’s not in the shed. Did he say anything?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Just said he wanted to be alone. (a beat) He took his violin.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: Is he likely to do anything silly?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother. Run away and join a band.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Martin! His entire family’s almost certainly been wiped out! Show some compassion.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You mean the way he would, in my position?

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: I don’t doubt it for a moment. He’s been like a brother to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And a son to you.  43 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.46

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: If there’s some secret place you boys have I’ve no need to know where it is. Just go there and find him. Martin goes out without a word.

dialogues.speaker: ENID
dialogues.text: David isn’t the suicidal type.

dialogues.speaker: GILBERT
dialogues.text: All artists are the suicidal type. EXT. HAMPSTEAD HEATH. NIGHT (SAME NIGHT) (W’47) 43 We find Martin and Dovidl sitting under a tree in their private place on the margin of Hampstead Ponds: Martin smoking a cigarette, Dovidl a pipe. The sepia family portrait we saw in Scene 21 is lying bes Dovidl on the grass. The Gagliano, out of its case, hangs bizarrely from a branch by the loose end of one its strin

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: My father thinks you’ve topped yourself. Dovidl smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Against my religion.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prodigal quasi-son wanted home, Dov.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Goody. Quasi-fatted calf for din- dins.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You really are a cold bastard, you know that? He flops down beside his friend.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (indicating the violin) It’s that thing I’m killing: the varnished tyrant. I’m glad you came. Murder needs witnesses. Noticing the photograph, Martin picks it up and studies i  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.47

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (of the photo) Why haven’t I seen this?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: It’s how I’ve kept them safe. Hiding them. From everyone.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m not everyone. Martin picks it up, studies it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Which one’s Malkeh? Dovidl points.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: She's five there. Pessia was nine.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What was it like? That life?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Still Life with Jews. Boys playing football, old men praying, ritual baths for the women. Malkeh was too young for that so she would stay home - I’d play her a lullaby at bedtime. My father would wander the streets - every day, Mottl, imagine - every evening except the sabbath - selling his jewellery, pieces he made while the rest of us were asleep. Just so we could eat. Sometimes we didn’t... Emotion catches him by the throat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s only presumption of death. Why your rabbi won’t let you say kiddish, right? Dovidl manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Kiddush is the blessing over wine. I can still say that. This is the Kaddish: (closes his eyes) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.48 DOVIDL (cont'd) Yisgadal v’yisqadash sh’mai rabah...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Don’t, Dov. Not if you’re not supposed to.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Do you think I’d go mad if I knew for certain? Strip off and run naked through the streets like Wechsler, waving my violin. “Israelites to your bows! The Philistines are upon us!”

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t think he did that.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Can’t see it working in Hampstead.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Wechsler started out half barmy.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: And I’m not?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You’ve got me.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: A stabilising influence.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Ordinary and boring.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Good for leaning on. Like this tree.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Nice to know I’m good for something.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Stop fishing for compliments, Mottl. This is my life crisis, not yours.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hey, how about a joint life crisis? Joint suicide note. We don’t have to do it, just drive my father nuts. Dovidl laughs.  44 45 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.49

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Do you think he'll ever recover?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Wechsler. Will he stay mad for ever, do you think? What do they do to lunatics in Poland, I wonder? Ice cold baths? Heap ashes on your head? It’s a place of ashes, Mottl. It'd be exactly the right treatment. INT. ASYLUM, WARSAW. DAY (S’86) 44 Nothing much has changed here since the place was built i the 1920s. Martin makes his way along a corridor of gloss brown tiled walls and shiny linoleum floors to a receptionist’s window, where he shows a piece of paper bearing Jozef Wechsler’s name to a MALE RECEPTIONIST. Aft staring at the name for long seconds the receptionist poi along the corridor. INT. ASYLUM VISITING ROOM. DAY (S’86) 45 Martin has been directed to a small, bare room with an ir grille over its single high window and walls covered in faded, yellowed paint more than sixty years old. JOZEF WECHSLER (now 65) is wheeled in by a NURSE almost a old as the asylum itself. She positions him under the win Haggard and sallow, looking nearer eighty, Jozef is rocki rhythmically to and fro in his wheelchair, as though in mockery of Jewish prayer; his long, once-nimble fingers fiddling compulsively with the buttons of his striped pyjamas. Nobody here has thought to avoid the cruel irony those stripes upon a Jewish patient bereaved into madness the Holocaust. Martin has brought grapes. Handing them to the nurse, he pulls up a hard, upright chair and seats himself by Jozef The nurse remains standing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Jozef? Do you remember me? Martin Simmonds? From London? No response from Jozef.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: David Rapoport was my foster brother. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You and he played together during an air raid - in Hampstead. (no reaction from Jozef) You came here with my father on a concert tour after the war. Jozef seems entirely unaware of his presence. Martin appeals silently to the nurse for help.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You are friend from Pan Wechsler?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I knew him in London, before... Before. Does he understand me?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Sometimes he remembers. (to Jozef) Your friend has come far for to see you, Jozef. Jozef, still rocking back and forth, says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (to nurse) Don’t you have any pyjamas that aren't striped?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Pyjamas...?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: They look like... Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You are good friend?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Friend of a friend. I was wondering... if someone we knew in London ever visited him. Another violinist. (a beat) David Rapoport?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Jozef has not much visitor. His family is dead. (a beat) Just only the woman.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: June 15 woman. She comes one day every year. June 15. (disapprovingly) Not his wife. EXT. WARSAW APARTMENT BLOCKS. DAY (S’86) 46 We're in an area of post-war apartment blocks in pale colours, with a few green verges. Could be anywhere. INT. ANNA’S APARTMENT BUILDING. DAY (S’86) 47 Entering one of the buildings, Martin climbs five flights iron-banistered stairs to the fifth floor. This time we m think he’s close, the elusive Dovidl perhaps only a few s away... He rings a doorbell. Waits. The door is opened - though only partially - by a tall, slender woman with high cheekbones, blue eyes, a small, straight nose and short blonde hair: recruiting poster fo the mature Aryan matron. ANNA WOZNIAK, 50 but looking younger.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Pani Wozniak? Anna Wozniak? A nod, slightly suspicious. Despite Solidarnosc and the t it has already begun to bring, the secret police are stil active in 1986; they come in all guises.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you speak English? Another nod.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m told you might be able to help me... INT. ANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY (S’86) 48 Like the Simmonds house, this is the living space of a cultured person on a strict budget: many books, few furnishings.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I hardly know Pan Wechsler. I visit him as a duty.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: One day a year. June 15th.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Mind if I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm trying to find someone who knew him in London. Another violinist. David Rapoport. Anna’s reaction tells Martin he’s struck gold.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (realization) You are Martin! INT. ANNA’S APARTMENT. DAY - LATER (S’86) 48A CLOSE ON a framed portrait of Pope John Paul II hanging o wall and a simple wooden crucifix fixed above it. Martin is looking at them as Anna returns to the room wit coffee tray.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: David came the year your queen was coronated. I lived then on Dzielna, where he grew up. It is how we met.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How long did he stay in Warsaw?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: A few months. He was not allowed a visa for very long.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Any idea where he went after that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: This he did not tell me. Though Anna is more forthcoming now that she knows who Ma is, we sense that she’s not yet entirely trusting. She sees that he’s looking at the crucifix.  49 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018)

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: They are allowed in private homes. I took them down when David was with me. p-53 There’s an implication of intimacy in “with me” that Mart doesn’t acknowledge.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It would not have pleased him to see them, I think.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, he’s not a big fan of religion.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Your friend is a soul... on pause. Is there a word for that? Martin shakes his head, unsure what she means.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Believing one thing, another thing, nothing - all at the same time?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
