dialogues.text: Agnostic? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ambivalent?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. David was ambivalent. EXT. NORTH LONDON STREETS. EARLY MORNING (S’47) 49 The boys are walking to the synagogue early on a summer’s morning. Dovidl carrying a velvet prayer bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What’s this thing I’m supposed to witness?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: A ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Not another bar mitzvah!?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Not quite.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Bit early to raise one of those quorum thingies.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.54

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: This doesn’t need a minyan. Just a witness.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Nice to count for once.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Probably not to God, Mottl. Only to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you think He knows where your family is? God.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Oh, He knows, He just won’t say. Would Jesus if you asked him? Martin smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why? Thinking of converting?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Jews can’t convert.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Disraeli did.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Disraeli was baptised. Wetting his head didn’t wash the Jew out of him. Or out of Jesus. Ethnicity isn’t soluble in water, Mottl. Religion - well, that’s a coat. When it gets too hot you can take it off. They arrive at the synagogue and enter. INT. SYNAGOGUE. EARLY MORNING (S’47) 50 Empty pews, unoccupied bimah, a few stragglers leaving af the Shacharit service. The red glow of the Eternal Light the Ark signifies the continuing presence of God.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You just lost your minyan.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.55

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: No, this is perfect. (indicating the Eternal Light) He’s here. The ceremony’s for Him. He pulls from his prayer bag a striped silk tallith, whic drapes about his neck, and the embroidered kippah he wore his bar mitzvah, which he places on his head.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Listen and don’t interrupt. (intoning, to the Eternal Light) Hear, O Israel and the God of Israel. On this nineteenth day of Sivan in the year 5707, in London, in the presence of Martin Simmonds, also of London I, David Eli Rapoport, son of Zygmunt and Esther Rapoport of Warsaw, do freely and of my own will renounce the faith of my forefathers...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Converting. Be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Nothing. (continuing his ceremony) I do most solemnly renounce and repudiate, now and for ever, in the name of the surviving, the reviled and discredited faith of the perished: the faith of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob...

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This isn’t funny, Dov-

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: ... the accursed faith of the despised, the mocked, the persecuted, the slaughtered; the faith abandoned by Jesus. Thus do I renounce the Torah and Talmud. Thus do I divorce myself from the community of Israel... Dipping into his bag, he extracts a knife. With the praye shawl still around his neck, he begins to cut it into pie  51 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.56 Martin has stepped back in horror. Though not himself a practising Christian, he knows the momentousness of self- excommunication.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: YOU CAN’T DO THIS!

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: ..-And, as I separate this garment, so do I separate myself, now and for all time, from the beliefs, practices, traditions, rituals and obligations of Zion. The tallith has drifted from his neck in tatters. Pulling skull cap from his head, Dovidl cuts it in half and drops pieces at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Amen. His footsteps resonate on the tiled floor as he leaves. Martin stares silently after him. EXT. BALCONY OF ANNA’S APARTMENT, WARSAW. DUSK (S’86) 51 Anna has brought Martin on to the balcony of her apartmen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reconstructed square of post-war apartment blocks built the site of the razed ghetto: a site as displaced in time that of any ancient battlefield, this one echoless by des

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If this is where the Ghetto was, where are the ruins?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Where the past belongs. Under the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So he just left, didn’t say where he was going?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Must we have these interrogations, Martin, like a Sherlock Holmes story?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s why I’m here. (a beat) Where was he staying? Didn’t he come to say goodbye?  Blue - SoN D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.56A Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: For his first days, in a pension - not a very good one.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Where after that?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: With me. 52 INT. WARSAW BISTRO. NIGHT (S’86) 52 Over dinner, vodka flowing freely-  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.57

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He used you. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Martin, I loved your friend. It’s how you live with people you don’t always like. By loving them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Loving Dovidl’s a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We don’t choose who to love.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (anger building) Trusting him’s a mistake. You can’t trust them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Them?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Artists. They die, they disappear, they leave you. They don’t understand love or loyalty.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You must stop looking for him, Martin. It would not be good to find him.  53 54 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.58

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: For him or me?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Both. If he wanted to be found don’t you think he would have come to you long ago? The anger that has been building in Martin bursts out.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We thought he was dead! My father gave up on life when he disappeared! Had a stroke two months later. It killed him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: David told me of your friendship. Not how it ended. Reaching across the table, Anna covers Martin’s hand with own.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He is the soloist. We are the accompanists. He took our light. We have none of our own.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t accept that.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. You do. (a beat) We use each other. EXT. ANNA’S APARTMENT BLOCK. NIGHT (S’86) 53 Re-establishing. INT. ANNA’S APARTMENT. NIGHT (S’86) 54 DISCOVER MARTIN in bed with Anna. Post-coital. For him it as though he has performed the act under some irresistibl compulsion. Anna senses it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You have never done this before? Been unfaithful to your wife?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: How does it feel?  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.59

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Like betrayal. He turns his head to look at her. Is this why she lured h into her bed? To show him the obverse face of betrayal? S reads the question in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Where did he go when he left Poland, Anna?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Again this? I told you, he did not say.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you. He points at a crucifix over the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Swear on that.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh, Martin, that cross has heard more lies than... Goebbels’ bathroom mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Swear anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I swear on the holy cross he did not tell me where he went.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why do you visit Wechsler?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I told you this also. I go in place of David.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How often did he go?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Once only. To play for him the Song. June 15th, 1953. He never went again.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What song?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Martin, it’s why David came to Poland. To play the music where the ashes are. It was his obsession.  55 56 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.60

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: There is nothing to tell. I was not permitted to hear it. He sent me from the room when he played for Jozef. The only other time I was made to wait in the car... when I took him to Treblinka. INT./EXT. ANNA’S CAR/TREBLINKA. DAY (S‘86) 55 Anna’s Polski Fiat passes a small roadside kapliczka [Catholic monument] as they approach Treblinka. EXT. TREBLINKA - SYMBOLIC CEMETERY ENTRANCE. DAY (S’86) 5 Anna drives in and stops by a sculpture representing rail tracks at the entrance to the symbolic cemetery. Beyond t memorials the forest can be seen encroaching at the perimeter: still raw, undressed, startled by discovery. Anna shuts off the engine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: This is where I waited. None of this was here. Only fields, some railway tracks.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Did he tell you about his family? Pessia would have been fifteen, Malkeh ten or eleven. They never appeared on any lists. We encouraged him to keep hoping. Maybe we shouldn’t have.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He never spoke of them. To David Jews were not Poles. I ama Pole, I live where he lived, I stole his life. To him I am one of the persecutors.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You were just a child then.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be guilty to feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.61 EXT. TREBLINKA - THE SYMBOLIC CEMETERY. DAY (S’86) 56A DISCOVER MARTIN AND ANNA walking through the symbolic cemetery: a garden of stone slabs of various sizes, each representing an annihilated Jewish community. Neither Anna nor Martin speaks as they wander among the stones, reading the names of villages, towns, cities; her only the dead do the talking. Martin stops by the largest stone of all, inscribed “WARSZAWA”, contemplates it in silence... INT. AIRPORT TERMINAL. DAY (S’86) 57 As they approach the airport terminal in Anna’s Fiat Pols

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: The morning after, he was gone. He left behind everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What’s everything?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Me. Poland. His past. You. (a beat) The violin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. He left the Gagliano? Anna’s Polski pulls up outside the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I found it after he went - I couldn’t believe he did that on purpose. Something so precious. I went in a taxi to the airport to return it. (a beat) He told me to sell it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And send him the money?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: The money I was to keep.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It was not mine to sell.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: His either.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That is why he took it back. Retrieving his bag from the back seat, Martin opens the passenger door. Unsure how to conduct the valediction.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So... I suppose this is goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I never lied to you, Martin. He never told me where he was going. (moment of decision) When I was giving him the violin a flight was called. Suddenly he was in a hurry. (a beat) The flight was to New York. ON MARTIN: a surge of excitement pulsing through him; a t thirty-three years cold but still a trail.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (kissing her) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: God bless you, Martin. I would say I hope you find him... but I hope you do not. Martin closes the car door, heads into the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 58
dialogues.text: INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE. NIGHT (S’86) 59 Martin returns from his travels to a house in semi-darkne The hall light is on but Helen isn’t in the living room, in the kitchen...  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.63

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (calling) Helen? No answer. He climbs the stairs and enters the bedroom, where he fin Helen in bed, reading. Her eyes flick up, then back to th book.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What’re you reading? She shows him the cover. Making a Difference: Feminist Literary Criticism by Kahn and Green [published 1985].

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me the ending. Ignored by Helen, Martin busies himself unpacking his suitcase, removing his jacket etc.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t find him. Thanks for asking. No response.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I know where he went after Poland. Still nothing back from Helen.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONTD.)
dialogues.text: New York.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Next stage of the ‘Great Quest’? Martin seats himself on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You don’t care if I find him, do you? Helen shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Why? You used to like him.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (raising the book) I used to like pony stories.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He was fun to be around.  60 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.64

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Charismatic genius and all that. Except geniuses aren’t very good at being human.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I know his faults, okay. I’ve known them a lot longer than you have.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Then why waste your time on him? Our time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I may be all he’s got.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I’m all you’ve got. It takes a moment for the import of this to register.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He’s not a fucking rival, love. Now she looks up, meets his eye.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He was from the day I met him. JAUNTY JEWISH BAND MUSIC OVER - the Hora Nayeem, played w some unusual strings riffs-

dialogues.speaker: INT. DANCE HALL, LONDON. NIGHT, (MAY, 1948)
dialogues.text: ON DOVIDL the source of the riffs. Having joined the band for the length of the song, he is seated cross-legged on the floor in front of the cellist, bowing the strings while the cellist does the fingering: party trick which is drawing loud applause from everyone the hall. HELEN and MARTIN (both 18 here) are watching this: Helen fascination. She hasn’t met Dovidl yet. The occasion is a celebratory dance: the hall hung with Israeli flags, portraits of Ben-Gurion, a banner declarin the date (May 14th, 1948) and proclaiming the birth of th State of Israel. In one corner a recruitment stand has been set up, a coup of tanned sabras in khaki shirts enjoining North Londoner enlist in the new army, to fight the massed Arab hordes preparing to destroy their infant nation. “ISRAEL NEEDS Y reads the sign.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.65 The song ends and Dovidl makes his way through the crowd Martin, the band now playing Bublitschki.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming, Mottl. (eyeing Helen) Ah, the much-advertised Helen. No interest in Israel, I assume, but Mottl’s here for me, so you’re here for him, yes?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: A dance is a dance.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (to Helen) My brother: Dov the Apostate. Not soluble in water.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (indicating recruiters) Shall I join up and shed blood for Israel, Mottl? The baby’s one day old and already bashing up its neighbours, keyneynahora.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I think they’re only taking Jews, Dov.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: There goes our reputation for draft- dodging. (to Helen) But they do take women. One up on God.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: If you're an apostate how come you're celebrating a Jewish state?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: They give great parties. Never missed one yet.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: When was the last one?

dialogues.speaker: B.C.
dialogues.text: Dovidl offers his hand. Helen takes it, allows herself to led onto the dance floor. Martin is left abandoned.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.66

dialogues.speaker: INT. TAXI. NIGHT, (MAY, 1948)
dialogues.text: Dovidl is lolling drunkenly against Helen in the back sea eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sorry about this. We can dump him and go back if you want.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay. Drop me off first. (a beat) I haven’t seen him at lectures. Is he in our year?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He isn’t at UCL. Trinity, Cambridge, reading Maths.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (pulls a face) Maths!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Music plus chess equals maths. Simmonds’ Equation. Helen’s eyebrows go up. Dovidl’s being a science major ma him doubly exotic. She brushes a stray lock of hair out o Dovidl’s eyes, which open at her touch.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Dead and gone to heaven. “L'amor che muove il sole e l'altre stelle.”

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to be impressed?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: You kidding? Maths and Dante? Helen laughs. The taxi pulls up outside a terraced house. Helen climbs out.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you, Dovidl. She closes the taxi door and is gone. As the taxi moves off-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (eyes still closed) Impregnable fortress. Best of British luck with that one, brother. INT. SIMMONDS HOUSE, DINING ROOM. NIGHT (S’86) 61A Alone in the house, Helen is working her way through a bo memorabilia. We'll see, among other things: the programme for Dovidl’s aborted 1951 debut concert; a faded newspaper clipping fr the following day, headlined: “VIOLINIST MISSING”, 21-yea old Dovidl pictured; and, most prominent, the sleeve to t promotional recording referred to in Scene 1: featuring Dovidl’s rendering of the BACH PARTITAS, which we'll hear playing over. Helen's face is registering a complex emotional cocktail that’s tricky to read: transportation, nostalgia, dislike regret... and something else... INT. LONDON CONCERT HALL. AFTERNOON (A’51) 62 The orchestra is packing up its instruments, preparing to leave after the final acoustic rehearsal. Dovidl casing h Gagliano.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You should lock that in the dressing room. It'll be safe there.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Did Ulysses lock away his bow?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If it was pissing down in Ithaca, absolutely. (nervous ) How do you feel? Are you nervous about tonight? I’m not nervous. How do you think the rehearsal went? Dovidl grins. “Nervous” isn’t in his lexicon.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: How did it sound?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Great. Terrific. Magic.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: It was crap.  63 64 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.68

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good crap, though.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Great rehearsal, crap performance. Crap rehearsal, great performance.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now? (checks watch) You've got... four and a half hours.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Get drunk.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, so droll. International debut of David Eli Rapoport: tiddly fiddly-comedian. Isaac Stern meets Vic Oliver. Know what you ought to do? Seriously? Relax. I mean totally. (as Edward G. Robinson) Take my advice, kid. Get yourself laid.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: That what you’re going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Me? I’m doing haircut and manicure. Pull out my hair in handfuls, bite my nails to the quick.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (a smile) See you in the trenches. He wanders off. Martin watches him go. INT. YELLOW CAB, MANHATTAN. DAY (S’86) 63 A yellow cab in traffic. Martin in the back seat, studyin list of auction houses and specialist dealers in classica stringed instruments. Several names have already been cro off. The next on the list is “FEINMAN BROTHERS”. EXT. FEINMAN BROTHERS, MANHATTAN. DAY (S’86) 64 Martin enters a shop in a lower Manhattan side street:

dialogues.speaker: "FEINMAN BROTHERS
dialogues.text: VALUATIONS”.  65 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.69 INT. FEINMAN BROTHERS. CONTINUOUS (S’86) 65 The old man who emerges at the sound of the shop’s bell i Manhattan counterpart of Mr Bailey, only at least 20 year older.

dialogues.speaker: FEINMAN
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a Gagliano violin. Feinman smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FEINMAN
dialogues.text: Father, son or grandson? Alessandro or one of the Nicolos?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Nicolo Filio. Made in 1735.

dialogues.text: Nobody changes. Least of all him.  82 83 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.84

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He’s got his religion back.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He’s the same selfish arsehole he always was. In a black coat. (a beat) Can he still play?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He says so. That’s his risk.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: What’s he risking? No reply from Martin.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: This is exactly what your father did. You'll spend every penny we've got, he won’t turn up, you’ll have a stroke, you'll die, he won’t even come to the funeral. Again Martin declines to respond. EXT. KOSHER RESTAURANT, LONDON. NIGHT (A’86) 82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. KOSHER RESTAURANT. NIGHT (CONTINUOUS) (A’86) 83 CAMERA FINDS Martin and Helen at a table set for three, eating breadsticks and drinking mineral water. Waiting. H seems distinctly nervous, looking at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It’s now ten to eight.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: In artistic circles that isn’t even late for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Has he told you the programme yet? Martin shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: One of his conditions.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Probably show tunes. Rusty virtuoso plays the best of Broadway.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.85

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: For that he wouldn’t need to rehearse.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: You've seen him rehearsing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He won’t let me in the room. That was his other condition. He knows my father’s watching. He thinks God’s watching.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Same old audience. Everyone he’s let down before.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It gives him the illusion of control-

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Newsflash, Martin. If the illusion’s good enough only the magician can tell it isn’t the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I can tell. DOVIDL has entered. As always now, in ultra-orthodox dres

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Martin. Helen. You've aged well. Under strict orthodox rules he may not touch a woman who not his wife, so there’s no kiss, no handshake. Helen’s l is unwelcoming, guarded. She doesn’t answer. Dovidl smile He seats himself, picks up the menu, starts to peruse it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That's it? After 35 years? Hello- Helen-what’s-for-dinner?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He’s hungry. He’s been rehearsing silence all day. Dovidl smiles at her over the menu.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Everything okay? Hotel all right?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Adequate.  Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.86

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Dov, I know we agreed you select the programme, but as the organizer of this concert I need to confirm some things.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: That it won’t include “Doh a deer, a female deer.”

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: That isn’t in the programme. No response from Dovidl. Helen’s look to Martin says: “Wh did I tell you?”

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Dovidl, if you make a fool of me I‘1l kill you.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: (to Dovidl) Or I will. That’s not an idle threat, by the way. Dovidl smiles again. Taps the menu.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: None of this is kosher.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: It’s a kosher restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: To them, not to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay, just tell me how long it’1l be. The programme. Dovidl sets down the menu, picks up the wine list.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: How long was the original?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That what you’re doing? The ‘51 programme? The Bruch and the Partitas?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Isn't it what you wanted?  84 85 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.87

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (surprised but delighted) Well, yes, but... No, no, that’s great.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Does it matter? Look at him. He isn’t going to be there. Are you, David? Now Dovidl produces from his pocket and unfolds the 1951 concert programme. Slides it across the table to Martin. Helen cranes to see.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: This is the ‘51 programme!

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (without looking up) The wines aren’t kosher either. EXT. CONCERT HALL, LONDON. DAY (A’86) 84 The same concert hall we saw in earlier scenes. Martin approaching the building on foot. dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr Simmonds.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Can’t I just put my ear to the door?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: Won't help. It’s soundproof. Martin puts his ear to the door. Shrugs. Nothing audible.  86 87 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.88

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Have you heard him playing?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY MAN
dialogues.text: Like I said, soundproof. The door opens. Dovidl comes out carrying his violin case

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Still warm. Want to feel? As he passes Martin-

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (emotional) Dov... Dovidl turns.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You won’t let me down, will you?

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: No, Mottl. I won’t let you down. EXT. CONCERT HALL. NIGHT (A’86) 86 Outside crowds swarm and jostle on the sidewalk, as they thirty-six years ago. History in the remaking. dialogues.text: Thank you, God. INT. 1951 LONDON CONCERT HALL. NIGHT (A’51) 90 ON GILBERT after his cancellation announcement, shamed an broken; a ruined man financially, professionally and emotionally; the auditorium empty. INT. 1986 CONCERT HALL. NIGHT (CONTINUATION OF SC.89)(A’8

dialogues.text: (grudgingly) He can still play. I’1l give him that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was good. Dovidl is bowing to the audience, leaving the stage to appreciative but not overwhelming applause. The audience begins to flow out in the direction of the lobby.  92 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.91

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: (to Martin) Well?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good. It was good.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: It was crap.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good crap, though. Dovidl smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DOVIDL
dialogues.text: Wait fifteen minutes. He disappears to his dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Is it me, or isn’t he being just a little too compliant? Martin nods his agreement. A similar sense of foreboding gripped him too: a fear that Dovidl’s uncharacteristic compliance so far may have been a magician’s misdirection presaging some outrageous act of rebellion still to come. since the concert’s second half is scheduled to be a solo performance without orchestra, Dovidl will have all the latitude he needs to go rogue. ANGLE ON THE STAGE - being cleared of chairs and music stands.

dialogues.text: The orchestra musicians leaving for the night, packing aw their instruments, putting on their coats... INT. CONCERT HALL AUDITORIUM. NIGHT (A’86) 92 The second half of the concert is about to commence. The audience has returned and is waiting expectantly, clearin its collective throat. Unaccompanied solo performances ar the acid test: nobody to cover the violinist’s mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN AND HELEN
dialogues.text: standing now at the back of the hall. All the tension we in them before the concert has returned in the last fifte minutes. Now Dovidl makes his second entrance. Wearing this time, the amusement of all, the long black coat and fedora of u orthodox uniform.  93 94 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.92 Something’s coming, and it isn’t Bach. We know what it is what it has to be. We’ve known it for some while. As Dovidl waits for the embarrassed titters to die away w witness for the last time that now-familiar ritual: the l upward sweep of the rosin, the long downward sweep, and finally the blessing of his lips. Setting his bow gently to the Gagliano - the gesture of a lover - Dovidl opens with a single note so pure and mourn so protracted, so tender, that even in this initial strok of the instrument we realize that the first half of the concert wasn’t misdirection at all, it was foreplay. This though they don’t know it yet, is what the audience came Many of them are checking their programmes, puzzled, as i Martin, not to be hearing Bach.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARTIN AND HELEN
dialogues.text: They exchange a look. Uh-oh. And now, for the first time, we’ll hear David Eli Rapopor solo violin version of The Song of Names, composed in 195 London in fidelity to his vow: a complex, exquisitely harmonized arrangement of the simple sung melody that cha his life. It should be at once unbearably soulful, immediately memorable and technically stunning; a masterwork of nuanc and colour and shadow; a description in music of a People suffering, delivered via the ear to the blood. At first we’ll hear only the single voice of the Gagliano playing the original sung melody... INT. WARSAW ASYLUM. DAY (S’53) 93 .--and then a second violin enters in harmony - playing a variation on the melody - as we see DOVIDL (23) play The of Names for JOZEF WECHSLER (32 here but looking fifty). Outside the room Anna can be seen listening to Dovidl’s playing. EXT. TREBLINKA. IN SHOT, in the background, by the original railway track yet devoid of symbolic representation, Anna waits in her [not the Polski; probably a Trabant].  95 96 97 Blue - SON D9.1 (09/20/2018) p.93 INT. dialogues.speaker: CU DOVIDL
dialogues.text: as he finishes playing The Song of Names in public for th first and only time. He draws out the final perfect melancholy note as long as possible, before fading slowly to silence. Then nothing. THE AUDIENCE - stunned into a silence of their own. MARTIN - moved beyond the capacity to move. When, seconds later, the audience recovers itself, their applause lifts the roof. Dovidl bows low. Then leaves the stage. There will be no encore. There will be no return. The rest is coda. INT. DRESSING ROOM. Just discarded suit over the back of a chair, on its seat the cased Gagliano, and on the violin case- AN ENVELOPE ADDRESSED TO MARTIN.
